406F387F49E645BA9E7C3A5288E66402.description: explain the role of plant tropism (e.g., response to stimuli such as light, gravity, and humidity) in a plant's survival

2ACB397517884B75AF93927E4F09B999.description: explain the relationship between the structure of a plant and its external environment, and describe the adaptive attributes that result in natural variation in plant structure (e.g., environmental variables cause variation in leaves within a single plant; in the Arctic, the wild crocus grows close to the ground and is covered with fine hairs)

4D6737F811E84D26BC015CB8DEEB7CB6.description: explain the various roles of plants in the sustainability of the natural environment (e.g., in nutrient cycles, in the water cycle, in erosion control, in wildlife habitats)

59F0355B78FD4D1E8EE059D38278202D.description: compare the various means of sexual reproduction (e.g., pollination) and asexual reproduction (e.g., grafting, vegetative propagation, cloning) in plants

718DE272201942F3B87749E65280B5E8.description: explain the chemical changes and energy transformations associated with the process of photosynthesis, and compare the reactants (i.e., carbon dioxide, radiant energy, water) to the products (i.e., glucose, oxygen)

527E9EE2130E4A99B09875D527675184.description: describe the structure and physiology of the specialized plant tissues involved in conduction, support, storage, and photosynthesis

79A74C38E56E41BD80D5BA358D371332.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of the structure and physiology of plants and their role in the natural environment.

306C7CC2E5474B73B30089F6B0CD5BE6.description: investigate plant tropism by growing and observing plants in a variety of natural and human-made environments

B9A5B28B95A848CB8E0C74D2D231CBA0.description: investigate how chemical compounds (e.g., fertilizers, herbicides, pesticides) and physical factors (e.g., amount of sun and water, quality of soil, pH of soil) affect plant growth

BF8A3B89452A4913AF24F786C42AF855.description: investigate various techniques of plant propagation (e.g., leaf cutting, stem cutting, root cutting, seed germination, traditional Aboriginal practices)

6B51674AF34341359EA7B6A6CC019752.description: use appropriate terminology related to plants in the environment, including, but not limited to: xylem, phloem, chloroplast, pistil, stamen, nitrogen fixation, and tropism

6DE2CF5FBBE940ED91BF1F9A5643F724.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate some of the factors that affect plant growth;

62AC8F96B8B0451DAD3A006B22F24708.description: assess the positive and negative impact of human activities on the natural balance of plants (e.g., crop rotation, the use of fertilizers and herbicides, the introduction of new species)

049BA07B1B60448CA31979308BB5B2FF.description: analyse, on the basis of research, and report on ways in which plants can be used to sustain ecosystems

6080060FEA104B32948A199DF1716121.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: analyse the roles of plants in ecosystems, and assess the impact of human activities on the balance of plants within those ecosystems;

BC2983CBE55F470A93E36185DEE05FBF.description: explain some of the mechanisms of interaction between a mammal's different body systems (e.g., the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide between the respiratory and circulatory systems)

132BCAE2722C4D3EAE20F8D226471B89.description: describe the anatomy and physiology of the digestive system (including the mouth, epiglottis, esophagus, stomach, intestines, liver, and pancreas), the mechanisms of peristalsis, absorption, and mechanical and chemical digestion, and the function of the kidneys

CE471B7818504B608CE2721D8CA92DC1.description: describe the anatomy and physiology of the respiratory system (including the nasal cavity, trachea, larynx, bronchi, bronchioles, alveoli, and oxygenated and deoxygenated blood) and the mechanisms of gas exchange and respiration

D9513DDD9C684435936EC0C04B75E8E7.description: describe the anatomy and physiology of the circulatory system (including the atrium, ventricles, valves, aorta, pulmonary artery, vena cava, capillaries, veins, arteries, blood cells, and platelets), the mechanisms of blood pressure, and the function of the spleen

34E7896D6C174961B35B85D6EC0618AF.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of the structure, function, and interactions of the circulatory, digestive, and respiratory systems of mammals.

12AE2DEC8F184D84A6F588D27D294E26.description: perform a laboratory or computer-simulated dissection of a mammal to identify organs, and explain the relationships between the structures and functions of body systems

8EB5B40EC3F64286A49E1F758B008F97.description: plan and conduct an inquiry to determine the effects of specific variables on the human body (e.g., the effects of exercise and rest on heart rates)

C23F984BF2524EC09D1B4D1F65EDB10A.description: use medical equipment (e.g., a stethoscope, a sphygmomanometer) to monitor a human system, and interpret the data collected

43971B7EBBB3454AA0AC502316ECE51F.description: use appropriate terminology related to animal anatomy, including, but not limited to: systolic contraction, diastolic pressure, diffusion gradient, inhalation, exhalation, coronary, cardiac, ulcer, asthma, and constipation

83A8ECF239C94FE1A8E1454B1CD1A19F.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate, through laboratory inquiry or computer simulation, the anatomy, physiology, and response mechanisms of mammals;

FC81A67448DC4F5B9650C898B1AC7613.description: analyse the impact of various lifestyle choices on human health and body systems (e.g., the impact of excessive alcohol consumption on the liver; of smoking on the respiratory system; of loud noise on the auditory system)

B758ED6C8FBC43D6AA1DC5AD39404365.description: analyse the social or economic impact of a medical device or technology related to the treatment of the human circulatory, respiratory, or digestive system (e.g., a pacemaker, a heartlung bypass machine, kidney dialysis)

7B3558BB0F624FA58904B0D146FAC535.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: analyse the social or economic impact of a technology used to treat systems in the human body, and the impact of lifestyle choices on human health;

1171FDE30DBE4443BAF71FF7DE684214.description: describe reproductive technologies such as cloning, artificial insemination, and in vitro fertilization

295DC95ADB0049FE902494E7491DE48E.description: describe some genetic disorders that are caused by chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., non-disjunction) or other genetic mutations

85B7DBBD9D36437F92A90F08736E1D2C.description: explain the concepts of genotype, phenotype, dominance, recessiveness, and sex linkage

F8950687205E4809B748262888B81DC4.description: explain how the concepts of DNA, genes, chromosomes, alleles, mitosis, and meiosis account for the transmission of hereditary characteristics from generation to generation

5072380DC3B3442AA2B80BF60C421030.description: explain the process of meiosis in terms of cell division and the movement of chromosomes

9B2321011E1C4366B7DB2B3EF1AAE7C6.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of the process of meiosis, and explain the role of genes in the transmission of hereditary characteristics

C824CBB7F1994B77907A461B1D6D3818.description: compile and analyse qualitative and quantitative data, through laboratory inquiry or computer simulation, on monohybrid crosses, and communicate the results (e.g., record data obtained while performing a "virtual fly" lab, and analyse the results to create a karyotype chart)

9A59BCC1E0AF411EA267E8F32A1E9381.description: solve basic problems in genetics that involve monohybrid crosses, using the Punnett square method

6E3EAD4366FA4B33A5D0F6F7AFF4A25A.description: investigate the process of meiosis, using a microscope or computer simulation, and identify, and draw biological diagrams of, the phases of meiosis

FCFEAEAA4CFD44A7AB10B3BA9253A662.description: use appropriate terminology related to genetics, including, but not limited to: spindle, haploid, diploid, heterozygous, homozygous, hemophilia, gamete, ultraviolet radiation, carcinogen, cancer, trisomy, somatic cell, and zygote

F9D40325F4914F31AFE07C8D7848FBEA.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate the process of meiosis, and analyse data related to the laws of heredity;

672D264B212747C3BB72C748F22FC7EB.description: evaluate, on the basis of research, some of the effects of genetic research and biotechnology (e.g., genetically modified organisms [GMOs]) on the environment

B58EBB800A0547E2ACD9AEBFA8F22C39.description: evaluate, on the basis of research, some of the social and ethical implications of genetic research and reproductive technologies (e.g., sex selection, harvesting umbilical cord cells)

816D5B1A1C6D4FBDAA37BBE9C13DB0B5.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: evaluate some social, ethical, and environmental implications of genetic research and related technologies;

1AEEADD619D1464092F793C06A4938CD.description: describe how different viruses, bacteria, and fungi can affect host organisms, and how those effects are normally treated or prevented (e.g., hepatitis viruses can damage the liver, but vaccinations can prevent infections; streptococcus bacteria can cause respiratory infections, which are treated with antibiotics; ringworm is a fungal infection of the skin, treated with fungicides)

BE4755F787404C7086BBF09CDB5263E2.description: explain the different methods of reproduction in various types of bacteria, viruses, and fungi

19BC904D50F54BBB82A57DFFF2DF8D34.description: explain the vital roles of microorganisms in symbiotic relationships with other organisms (e.g., gut bacteria in cows digest cellulose; mycorrhizal fungi penetrate and effectively extend a plant's root system)

ACF72282EC9C4F67B6376C8F2125F153.description: explain the differences between the life cycles of eukaryotic and prokaryotic microorganisms in terms of cell division

99DC0B240FCF4937B79364D0ADF90D26.description: describe the anatomy and morphology of various groups of microorganisms (e.g., eukaryotes, prokaryotes, viruses)

8C60F0E6C7724DC1A44F17861462CE15.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of the diversity of microorganisms and the relationships that exist between them

AE3840A8DA3F464D8998C6124CFBB4DE.description: investigate and analyse the conditions (e.g., optimal temperature) needed by microorganisms for growth

72D633945D854E9B9C977594DC86DFF2.description: investigate the effect of antibacterial agents on different bacterial cultures (e.g., the effects of antibacterial soap or mouthwash on a bacterial culture)

9A6F11723DD64D3F863C833B084CC523.description: prepare a laboratory culture of microorganisms (e.g., acidophilus) on agar, using proper aseptic techniques

3FDC9DBB1C654571825596CEA536EFC5.description: compare and contrast the cell structures of eukaryotes such as fungi, protozoa, and algae

8EE19CE4BAC24B938FBC5260CB41228D.description: use appropriate terminology related to microbiology, including, but not limited to: fission, conjugation, phage, dormancy, morphology, mycelium, spore, pathogen, and plasmid

4DBFD83116184D72A9932DA4277A34F5.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate the development and physical characteristics of microorganisms, using appropriate laboratory equipment and techniques;

4B84EBCE704A4A52953B91A66AB6591B.description: analyse ethical issues related to the use of microorganisms in biotechnology (e.g., with respect to the use of bacterial insecticides, the patenting of modified microorganisms)

35A0EA60CF67423C83344320D0CA84D8.description: assess some of the effects, both beneficial and harmful, of microorganisms in the environment (e.g., decomposers break down waste, E. coli in water systems poses a severe risk to human health)

997DF966B070473CAD704A3DA0219B8D.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: assess the effects of microorganisms in the environment, and analyse ethical issues related to their use in biotechnology;

D0D3FBADA9764C229738C43FFEDADCFA.description: explain the importance of various cellular processes in human systems (e.g., enzymes act as biological catalysts to regulate chemical processes in the cells of the digestive system

3B265058D1B44253A65B732E8FB2476C.description: explain the chemical changes and energy transformations associated with the process of cellular respiration, and compare the reactants (i.e., glucose, oxygen) to the products (i.e., water, carbon dioxide, ATP)

4B075B2D46BC4C14A8855246ADD2D91F.description: explain the roles of various organelles, including lysosomes, vacuoles, mitochondria, cell membranes, ribosomes, the endoplasmic reticulum, and Golgi bodies, in the processes of digestion, cellular respiration, and protein synthesis

795571014376403DAFE4553517F28D57.description: describe the structures and functions of important biochemical compounds, including carbohydrates, proteins, enzymes, and lipids

8417FAF432AE49E0B2F3079FBB8EE92C.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of the basic processes of cellular biology.

03548C22C6F94C9B97965CA15CA05557.description: conduct biological tests to identify biochemical compounds found in various food samples (e.g., use a biuret solution to test for proteins in samples of gelatin and albumin), and compare the biochemical compounds found in each food to those found in the others

1F3787D1D38848669D7ADAA13ED3F0C2.description: investigate the effects of various qualitative factors on the action of enzymes (e.g., the effect of temperature or pH on the breakdown of starch by salivary enzymes)

EFD3150895834D72834A789B1BF69458.description: using a light microscope, identify visible organelles of a plant cell in a wet mount and an animal cell from a prepared slide, produce an accurate labelled drawing of each cell, and calculate and properly express the magnification of each image

D996E688AFAB4EF885554BC016BC9576.description: investigate the effect of various qualitative factors (e.g., temperature) on the rate of diffusion of molecules across a plasma membrane

AD20B7C540074DF8B1FE9ED325B0C016.description: use appropriate terminology related to cellular biology, including, but not limited to: macromolecule, passive transport, active transport, catalyst, and fluid mosaic model

83FCF33A483142B09300A3BB0B9AEA18.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate the structures and functions of cells, and the factors that influence cellular activity, using appropriate laboratory equipment and techniques;

4DBBF37036EE4EEE8B06BA64F3489DFF.description: analyse the effects of environmental factors on cellular processes that occur in the human body (e.g., the effect of lead on nerve cells; the effect of electromagnetic radiation on brain cells)

A1276420EF0D440BBC8A47C7DD63D9FE.description: evaluate the effectiveness of medical devices and technologies that are intended to aid cellular functions or processes (e.g., insulin infusion pump, chemotherapy)

0097C4564FEA4C9E91FC0E4BE60C16E3.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: evaluate the impact of environmental factors and medical technologies on certain cellular processes that occur in the human body;

D6962BFD641540A689EA4FA6AF940E9F.description: describe the contributions of scientists, including Canadians (e.g., Julia Levy, Charles Beer, Shirley Tilghman, Walter Lewis, Gail Anderson), to the fields under study

59841FF9660D4ABF8B6BC82FEE5550BB.description: identify and describe a variety of careers related to the fields of science under study (e.g., food science technologist, medical laboratory technologist, dental hygienist, outpost clinic/primary care nurse, respiratory therapist, veterinary technician, water or wastewater technician) and the education and training necessary for these careers

D33C716B71004849AB9DC65037BF02A9.description: Career Exploration: . identify and describe careers related to the fields of science under study, and describe the contributions of scientists, including Canadians, to those fields.

E5F7E785BE3E46189594EF40B903F213.description: express the results of any calculations involving data accurately and precisely, to the appropriate number of decimal places and significant figures

3C8A844D4B3848098430807ACCD49C54.description: use appropriate numeric, symbolic, and graphic modes of representation (e.g., biological diagrams, Punnett squares), and appropriate units of measurement (e.g., SI and imperial units)

194611A142CD4B5083362B7AFFF64871.description: communicate ideas, plans, procedures, results, and conclusions orally, in writing, and/or in electronic presentations, using appropriate language and a variety of formats (e.g., data tables, laboratory reports, presentations, debates, simulations, models)

CBC0FE8BC4BD49AF9994B94D5043C3EB.description: draw conclusions based on inquiry results and research findings, and justify their conclusions with reference to scientific knowledge

990828D982E34C0B991B5AF63CCDA2E7.description: analyse the information gathered from research sources for logic, accuracy, reliability, adequacy, and bias

DE491FA5F9EE46EBAF01292F9C270E72.description: synthesize, analyse, interpret, and evaluate qualitative and/or quantitative data to determine whether the evidence supports or refutes the initial prediction or hypothesis and whether it is consistent with scientific theory; identify sources of bias and/or error; and suggest improvements to the inquiry to reduce the likelihood of error

25E7EF78003743AA9D122E3E44779C5A.description: select, organize, and record relevant information on research topics from a variety of appropriate sources, including electronic, print, and/or human sources, using suitable formats and an accepted form of academic documentation

936B9EBE8EE84223B9B44A2A46FB3B0D.description: compile accurate data from laboratory and other sources, and organize and record the data, using appropriate formats, including tables, flow charts, graphs, and/or diagrams

111B3BD5D6F54D80BD0382E1965DD659.description: conduct inquiries, controlling relevant variables, adapting or extending procedures as required, and using appropriate materials and equipment safely, accurately, and effectively, to collect observations and data

BACC9117979347BCAE408F276B1C2B9E.description: apply knowledge and understanding of safe laboratory practices and procedures when planning investigations by correctly interpreting Workplace Hazardous Materials Information System (WHMIS) symbols; by using appropriate techniques for handling and storing laboratory equipment and materials and disposing of laboratory and biological materials (e.g., preserved specimens); and by using appropriate personal protection

9892BAFA2A444BB2B77D68799A9ACAB8.description: identify and locate a variety of print and electronic sources that enable them to address research topics fully and appropriately

3850E596B6CA4299A1FB54BF323ABEFA.description: select appropriate instruments (e.g., a microscope, a stethoscope, plant-propagation instruments, dissection instruments) and materials (e.g., prepared slides, agar plates, plants), and identify appropriate methods, techniques, and procedures, for each inquiry

6EFD792C78044B8A897EC53566022AA3.description: formulate relevant scientific questions about observed relationships, ideas, problems, or issues, make informed predictions, and/or formulate educated hypotheses to focus inquiries or research

009419A1DEBE45B591F8616D532AE156.description: Scientific Investigation Skills: demonstrate scientific investigation skills (related to both inquiry and research) in the four areas of skills (initiating and planning, performing and recording, analysing and interpreting, and communicating);

9D843C67AF7245D1BF321BB8A624EF97.description: Scientific Investigation Skills and Career Exploration
